newsitem.title: BANGLADESH: Bangladesh to sell off state companies.
newsitem.headline: Bangladesh to sell off state companies.

text.p: Bangladesh Industries and Commerce Minister Tofael Ahmed said on Thursday the government would soon begin selling off 64 state-owned companies under the country's privatisation programme.
"We have to part with public enterprises at any cost or our development efforts are bound to falter," Ahmed told members of the Overseas Correspondent Association of Bangladesh (OCAB).
Ahmed said international tenders would be floated for the sale of the companies soon.
Ahmed said state-owned companies suffered $572 million in losses yearly, equal to one third of the annual foreign aid Bangladesh receives.
"Resistance from labour unions, lack of interest from buyers and lengthy procedures had delayed the country's privatisation process," he said.
"We are under pressure from the World Bank. We are certain to disinvest the enterprises. We will offer a better compensation package to the labourers."
Ahmed said Bangladesh could attract huge foreign investment in energy and telecommunications.
Some $3.3 billion worth of foreign investment was registered with the Board of Investment (BOI) in the first six months of fiscal 1996/97 (July-June), BOI officials said.
The officials said Bangladesh could expect only 50 percent of the amount registered to be actually invested.

The actual investment was only $50 million out of $2.7 billion registered in 1995/96. "But the wide gap between the actual investment and registration was due mainly to political chaos that year," said one official.
Ahmed said the bulk of foreign investment was in the country's energy sector.
He said British Cairn Energy Plc, American Occidental Corp, United Meridian Corp, Halliburton Co and Unocal Corp were investing in the country's energy sector.
"The Asian Development Bank (ADB), which earlier suspended aid to Bangladesh's energy sector, has resumed fresh funding," he said.
Ahmed said Bangladesh was also seeking foreign investment in development of sea ports.
He said Bangladesh, as member of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), had liberalised its trade policy.
"We have removed all tariff and non-tariff barriers to pursue a free trade policy," he said.
"But at the same time we have paid the cost for a faster move to that (free trade) as our domestic industries suffered."
He said Bangladesh had signed a border trade treaty with Burma.
"And there will be such treaty with India. But we are now moving slow and cautiously," he said.
Bangladesh has an annual trade deficit of more than $1 billion with neighbouring India.
